* is [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong").
* can throw boulders.
* likes gems.
* can pick up weapons and food.

|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |                                                      |
| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 | [monst.c#line1431](/wiki/Monst.c#line1431 "Monst.c") |

A **storm giant**, H, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. The storm giant is a [giant humanoid](/wiki/Giant_humanoid "Giant humanoid") that has the highest [level](/wiki/Monster_level "Monster level") and [difficulty](/wiki/Monster_difficulty "Monster difficulty") of the [giants](/wiki/Giant_\(monster_attribute\) "Giant (monster attribute)") - it has [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision") and can be seen via infravision. Like all giants, storm giants will seek out [gems](/wiki/Gems "Gems"), weapons and other items to pick up, and can move over [boulders](/wiki/Boulder "Boulder"), pick them up and throw them.

A storm giant has a single weapon attack, and possesses [shock resistance](/wiki/Shock_resistance "Shock resistance").

[Eating](/wiki/Eating "Eating") a storm giant [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") has a 1⁄2 chance (50%) of granting shock resistance, and an independent 1⁄2 chance (50%) of increasing a character's [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength").

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

The attacks of storm giants and other sufficiently large monsters can inflict knockback, sending targets flying one or more squares.

Storm giants and other large humanoids can wear mummy wrappings.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Variants](#Variants)

  - [4.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [4.2 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [4.3 SpliceHack](#SpliceHack)
  - [4.4 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [4.5 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [5 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [6 References](#References)

## Generation

Storm giants may generate as peaceful towards chaotic characters, and can generate in small [groups](/wiki/Groups "Groups") of two to four.

Storm giants may appear among the hostile giant humanoids generated in [throne rooms](/wiki/Throne_room "Throne room") at dungeon levels 13 and below, and can also appear among the monsters randomly generated by [looting](/wiki/Looting "Looting") a [throne](/wiki/Throne "Throne") while [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused") and carrying gold (provided there is no [chest](/wiki/Chest "Chest") on the level).[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

Storm giants may appear among the random H that are part of the second quest monster class for [Cavepeople](/wiki/Cavepeople "Cavepeople"), and make up 6⁄175 (\~3.42%) of the monsters randomly generated on the [Caveman quest](/wiki/Caveman_quest "Caveman quest"). Storm giants may also appear among the random H that are part of the second quest monster class for [Valkyries](/wiki/Valkyrie "Valkyrie"), and make up 6⁄175 (\~3.42%) of the monsters that are randomly generated on the [Valkyrie quest](/wiki/Valkyrie_quest "Valkyrie quest"). In practice, this is unlikely to occur unless the character is at a particularly high experience level while inside their Quest branch.

Storm giants have a 1⁄2 chance (50%) of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") either a boulder or a [club](/wiki/Club "Club") with equal probability, and an independent chance of being generated with a small assortment of gems.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)[\[3\]](#cite_note-3) They are eligible for [offensive items](/wiki/Offensive_item "Offensive item"), [defensive items](/wiki/Defensive_item "Defensive item"), and [miscellaneous items](/wiki/Miscellaneous_item "Miscellaneous item").

## Strategy

Storm giants are usually not seen until late in the dungeon, and are not especially stronger than the other giants: they share the same 12 speed as [fire giants](/wiki/Fire_giant "Fire giant") and [frost giants](/wiki/Frost_giant "Frost giant") and have the same damage dice for their weapon attack as frost giants, but most characters that encounter them will already have sufficient experience with their kin, along with a source of [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed") and better defenses against dangerous [wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand") and other items. As with most giants, taking advantage of their low [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)") is generally a good idea.

## History

The storm giant first appears in [SLASH 6](/wiki/SLASH_6 "SLASH 6"), the last release of SLASH based on [NetHack 3.1.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.3 "NetHack 3.1.3"), and makes its vanilla debut in [NetHack 3.3.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.3.0 "NetHack 3.3.0").

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), the storm giant's difficulty is increased to 21. Storm giants may appear among the random H generated in [giant courts](/wiki/Giant_court "Giant court") and the [Giant Caverns](/wiki/Giant_Caverns "Giant Caverns").

All of the above information also applies to [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM").

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), storm giants are neutral-aligned and vulnerable to [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron"). They are always generated with a [two-handed sword](/wiki/Two-handed_sword "Two-handed sword"), a [helmet](/wiki/Helmet "Helmet"), a [chain mail](/wiki/Chain_mail "Chain mail"), a [pair of gloves](/wiki/Pair_of_gloves "Pair of gloves"), and a [pair of shoes](/wiki/Pair_of_shoes "Pair of shoes"), all of which are made to fit their size - this is independent of the existing chance of being generated with a club, due to an oversight in the code.

Storm giants may appear among the court of a [titan](/wiki/Titan "Titan")-ruled [throne room](/wiki/Throne_room#dNetHack "Throne room"), and can also appear as minions of [Manannan Mac Lir](/wiki/Manannan_Mac_Lir "Manannan Mac Lir").

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), the [Drinking Hall](/index.php?title=Drinking_Hall\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Drinking Hall (page does not exist)") [special level](/wiki/SpliceHack/Special_levels "SpliceHack/Special levels") is "staffed" by two storm giants.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), storm giants are capable of entering [berserker rages](/wiki/Berserk_\(EvilHack\) "Berserk (EvilHack)"), increasing their damage but making them more likely to hit monsters around them besides their intended target.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), storm giants can go berserk as in EvilHack.

## Encyclopedia entry

Giants have always walked the earth, though they are rare in these times. They range in size from little over nine feet to a towering twenty feet or more. The larger ones use huge boulders as weapons, hurling them over large distances. All types of giants share a love for men - roasted, boiled, or fried. Their table manners are legendary.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/mkroom.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 745](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mkroom.c#L745)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 183](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L183)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 706](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L706)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Storm giant

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
H storm giant
Difficulty 19
Attacks Weapon 2d12
H storm giant
Difficulty 19
Attacks

Weapon 2d12

Base level 16
Base experience 536
Speed 12
Base AC 3
Base MR 10
Alignment -3 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 2250
Nutritional value 750
Size Huge
Resistances shock
Resistances conveyed shock (50%), Increase strength (50%)

A storm giant:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • is carnivorous.
  • is a giant.
  • is nasty.
  • is strong.
  • can throw boulders.
  • likes gems.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • has infravision.
  • can be seen through infravision.
  • normally appears in small groups.
Reference monst.c#line1431

A storm giant, H, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. The storm giant is a giant humanoid that has the highest level and difficulty of the giants - it has infravision and can be seen via infravision. Like all giants, storm giants will seek out gems, weapons and other items to pick up, and can move over boulders, pick them up and throw them.

A storm giant has a single weapon attack, and possesses shock resistance.

Eating a storm giant corpse or tin has a 1⁄2 chance (50%) of granting shock resistance, and an independent 1⁄2 chance (50%) of increasing a character's strength.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

The attacks of storm giants and other sufficiently large monsters can inflict knockback, sending targets flying one or more squares.

Storm giants and other large humanoids can wear mummy wrappings.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Variants
    • 4.1 SLASH'EM
    • 4.2 dNetHack
    • 4.3 SpliceHack
    • 4.4 EvilHack
    • 4.5 Hack'EM
  • 5 Encyclopedia entry
  • 6 References

Generation

Storm giants may generate as peaceful towards chaotic characters, and can generate in small groups of two to four.

Storm giants may appear among the hostile giant humanoids generated in throne rooms at dungeon levels 13 and below, and can also appear among the monsters randomly generated by looting a throne while confused and carrying gold (provided there is no chest on the level).[1]

Storm giants may appear among the random H that are part of the second quest monster class for Cavepeople, and make up 6⁄175 (~3.42%) of the monsters randomly generated on the Caveman quest. Storm giants may also appear among the random H that are part of the second quest monster class for Valkyries, and make up 6⁄175 (~3.42%) of the monsters that are randomly generated on the Valkyrie quest. In practice, this is unlikely to occur unless the character is at a particularly high experience level while inside their Quest branch.

Storm giants have a 1⁄2 chance (50%) of being generated with either a boulder or a club with equal probability, and an independent chance of being generated with a small assortment of gems.[2][3] They are eligible for offensive items, defensive items, and miscellaneous items.

Strategy

Storm giants are usually not seen until late in the dungeon, and are not especially stronger than the other giants: they share the same 12 speed as fire giants and frost giants and have the same damage dice for their weapon attack as frost giants, but most characters that encounter them will already have sufficient experience with their kin, along with a source of speed and better defenses against dangerous wands and other items. As with most giants, taking advantage of their low MR score is generally a good idea.

History

The storm giant first appears in SLASH 6, the last release of SLASH based on NetHack 3.1.3, and makes its vanilla debut in NetHack 3.3.0.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, the storm giant's difficulty is increased to 21. Storm giants may appear among the random H generated in giant courts and the Giant Caverns.

All of the above information also applies to SlashTHEM.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, notdNetHack and notnotdNetHack, storm giants are neutral-aligned and vulnerable to iron. They are always generated with a two-handed sword, a helmet, a chain mail, a pair of gloves, and a pair of shoes, all of which are made to fit their size - this is independent of the existing chance of being generated with a club, due to an oversight in the code.

Storm giants may appear among the court of a titan-ruled throne room, and can also appear as minions of Manannan Mac Lir.

SpliceHack

In SpliceHack, the Drinking Hall special level is "staffed" by two storm giants.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, storm giants are capable of entering berserker rages, increasing their damage but making them more likely to hit monsters around them besides their intended target.

Hack'EM

In Hack'EM, storm giants can go berserk as in EvilHack.

Encyclopedia entry

Giants have always walked the earth, though they are rare in these times. They range in size from little over nine feet to a towering twenty feet or more. The larger ones use huge boulders as weapons, hurling them over large distances. All types of giants share a love for men - roasted, boiled, or fried. Their table manners are legendary.

References

  1. ↑ src/mkroom.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 745
  2. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 183
  3. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 706

A '''storm giant''', {{monsym|storm giant}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. The storm giant is a [[giant humanoid]] that has the highest [[Monster level|level]] and [[Monster difficulty|difficulty]] of the [[Giant (monster attribute)|giants]] - it has [[infravision]] and can be seen via infravision. Like all giants, storm giants will seek out [[gems]], weapons and other items to pick up, and can move over [[boulder]]s, pick them up and throw them. 

A storm giant has a single weapon attack, and possesses [[shock resistance]].

[[Eating]] a storm giant [[corpse]] or [[tin]] has a {{frac|2}} chance (50%) of granting shock resistance, and an independent {{frac|2}} chance (50%) of increasing a character's [[strength]].

{{upcoming|3.7.0|The attacks of storm giants and other sufficiently large monsters can inflict knockback, sending targets flying one or more squares.

Storm giants and other large humanoids can wear mummy wrappings.}}

==Generation==
Storm giants may generate as peaceful towards chaotic characters, and can generate in small [[groups]] of two to four.

Storm giants may appear among the hostile giant humanoids generated in [[throne room]]s at dungeon levels 13 and below, and can also appear among the monsters randomly generated by [[looting]] a [[throne]] while [[confused]] and carrying gold (provided there is no [[chest]] on the level).{{refsrc|src/mkroom.c|745|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

Storm giants may appear among the random {{white|H}} that are part of the second quest monster class for [[Cavepeople]], and make up {{frac|6|175}} (~3.42%) of the monsters randomly generated on the [[Caveman quest]]. Storm giants may also appear among the random {{white|H}} that are part of the second quest monster class for [[Valkyrie]]s, and make up {{frac|6|175}} (~3.42%) of the monsters that are randomly generated on the [[Valkyrie quest]]. In practice, this is unlikely to occur unless the character is at a particularly high experience level while inside their Quest branch.

Storm giants have a {{frac|2}} chance (50%) of [[Monster starting inventory|being generated with]] either a boulder or a [[club]] with equal probability, and an independent chance of being generated with a small assortment of gems.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|183|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|706|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} They are eligible for [[offensive item]]s, [[defensive item]]s, and [[miscellaneous item]]s.

==Strategy==
Storm giants are usually not seen until late in the dungeon, and are not especially stronger than the other giants: they share the same 12 speed as [[fire giant]]s and [[frost giant]]s and have the same damage dice for their weapon attack as frost giants, but most characters that encounter them will already have sufficient experience with their kin, along with a source of [[speed]] and better defenses against dangerous [[wand]]s and other items. As with most giants, taking advantage of their low [[Magic resistance (monster)|MR score]] is generally a good idea.

==History==
The storm giant first appears in [[SLASH 6]], the last release of SLASH based on [[NetHack 3.1.3]], and makes its vanilla debut in [[NetHack 3.3.0]].

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], the storm giant's difficulty is increased to 21. Storm giants may appear among the random {{white|H}} generated in [[giant court]]s and the [[Giant Caverns]].

All of the above information also applies to [[SlashTHEM]].

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], [[notdNetHack]] and [[notnotdNetHack]], storm giants are neutral-aligned and vulnerable to [[iron]]. They are always generated with a [[two-handed sword]], a [[helmet]], a [[chain mail]], a [[pair of gloves]], and a [[pair of shoes]], all of which are made to fit their size - this is independent of the existing chance of being generated with a club, due to an oversight in the code.

Storm giants may appear among the court of a [[titan]]-ruled [[Throne room#dNetHack|throne room]], and can also appear as minions of [[Manannan Mac Lir]].

===SpliceHack===
In [[SpliceHack]], the [[Drinking Hall]] [[SpliceHack/Special levels|special level]] is "staffed" by two storm giants.

===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], storm giants are capable of entering [[Berserk (EvilHack)|berserker rages]], increasing their damage but making them more likely to hit monsters around them besides their intended target.

===Hack'EM===
In [[Hack'EM]], storm giants can go berserk as in EvilHack.

The larger ones use huge boulders as weapons, hurling them over large distances.  All types of giants share a love for men - roasted, boiled, or fried.  Their table manners are legendary.
